awd_titl_txt: CRII: FET: Embedded neuromorphic circuits for real-time closed-loop biosensor data processing
awd_abstract_narration:
In the last decade, there has been a revolution in biosensor devices producing a wealth of new data from patients. Increased density of sensors, for example embedded in implantable organ-conformal bioelectronic platforms, can provide high-definition spatial and temporal data for increased accuracy of detection and diagnostics. However, gathering a large quantity of data is insufficient if it is not matched by powerful circuitry to process the data and apply a therapeutic response in sometimes as fast as milliseconds. The next generation of biomedical technologies requires novel computing that can be embedded non-intrusively and can translate large quantities of time-sensitive biomedical data into a life-saving response rapidly and energy-efficiently. Distributed neuromorphic computing can provide faster, lower-power and more compact implementations than conventional computing, especially if implemented with emerging device technologies like resistive switches or memristors. Such neuromorphic chips designed for distributed computing can be co-located with the sensors and actuators for closed-loop diagnostics and therapy. This project will provide the fundamental investigations into the requirements and architecture for such distributed closed-loop computing. This technology will impact research in biomedical engineering, opening the path to computing of large amounts multi-physics data gathered in-vivo from organs and artificial tissue. Long term, this work could benefit healthcare, when embedded neuromorphic chips are integrated in a stand-alone implantable system that can enable real-time diagnostics and painless therapy for patients. These findings are also directly transferable to other applications in need of embedded computing hardware such as microrobots and Internet of Things (IoT).

This project will develop a neuromorphic computing solution that can be reliably embedded with existing sensor and actuator organ-conformal platforms. The proposed technology is based on hybrid neuromorphic chips organized in a cellular neural network with recurrence. To demonstrate its potential, the computing platform is be prototyped and tested for the analysis of cardiac wavefronts, which have stringent time constants of milliseconds. Initially, theoretical investigations will focus on developing a hardware-mappable algorithm that can distinguish electrical storms from normal electrical wave patterns. Then, experimental work focuses on taping out a cellular neural network processing unit in a hybrid memristor / transistor (CMOS) technology and testing a small distributed network of such units. This work benefits from the use of cardiac animal and human data for testing, thanks to collaborators in the Biomedical Engineering Department at George Washington University. The prototype demonstration and the supporting simulations serve as hands-on materials in a class on neuromorphic hardware and in various outreach efforts planned as part of the new GWU Center for Women in Engineering. A PhD student is being recruited, and an undergraduate student and a high school student are to be involved in the design and testing of this computing platform.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to develop an advanced computational solution for detecting and treating cardiac arrhythmias using cellular neural networks mappable to emerging device technologies. These networks were designed to be potentially embedded within future medical devices, in order to provide real-time analysis and low-energy pain-free response to life-threatening cardiac events such as ventricular fibrillation. Firstly, we successfully developed a high-performance algorithm that can accurately identify abnormal electrical activity in the heart, distinguishing between normal rhythms and arrhythmias with high precision. This algorithm was tested on data obtained from a deidentiﬁed donor human heart from the Washington Regional Transplant Community, which was previously rejected for transplantation and donated for research. The dataset included complete recordings of several ﬁbrillation events, enabling the analysis of various wavefront patterns during ﬁbrillation as part of this work. In ideal conditions, the algorithm demonstrated accuracy levels above 99.7%, precision of 93.83%, sensitivity of 97.65%, and specificity of 99.8%. High values in these metrics are crucial for ensuring in the future reliable detection and timely intervention for life-threatening cardiac events. Even when considering hardware limitations, the network can achieve strong performance metrics, with over 96% accuracy, 92% precision, 99% specificity, and 93% sensitivity. The algorithm's success was supported by hyperparameter tuning and batch training, ensuring robustness across diverse datasets and conditions.

The proposed algorithm has also been integrated with openCARP, a simulation platform that has high fidelity in replicating human cardiac behavior. This allowed us to simulate the heart tissue and intricately explore the multifaceted dynamics of arrhythmias and their responses to diverse therapeutic interventions guided by the proposed cellular neural network algorithm. Termination pulses of different strength and duration were investigated at specific locations informed by the waveforms detected by the cellular neural network algorithm. Simulations using the openCARP platform validated the algorithm's efficacy in detecting ventricular fibrillation across two-dimensional and three-dimensional cardiac tissue models. While complete arrhythmia termination in simulation using the proposed algorithm, remains a work in progress, the simulations highlighted promising capabilities in disrupting arrhythmia rotors, potentially leading to arrhythmia termination and restoration of normal sinus rhythm.

The unit cell of the algorithm was translated on a hybrid hardware platform, using transistors and memristor devices in a 130nm node. The power consumption and delay for the computing unit are estimated at ~600 µW and 5.6µs respectively. The results are promising to develop the fast and efficient building blocks for a distributed network of chiplets, each performing local computations and communicating with its neighbors. This hardware design can allow for real-time data processing and energy efficient decision-making, essential for implantable cardiac medical devices. This project also advanced the field of memristor-based computing systems by developing a practical application for memristor-based cellular neural networks in medical devices. These advancements contribute to our understanding of how to leverage memristor-based hardware for real-time computing in medical applications, potentially transforming the way we approach cardiac care and other critical health areas.

These results support the development of memristive-based systems for energy-efficient and real time information processing in critical applications. The research results have been published in two journal and conference papers so far. The project has provided research opportunities for a postdoc, 2 PhD students, 3 undergraduate students and 2 high school students, with almost half underrepresented minorities or women. Alumni from this project have either continued their education or taken jobs in the industry, thus contributing to the semiconductor manufacturing workforce.
